trans-unit.source: Use the Azure Portal to create an Azure virtual machine (VM) running Linux with the Azure resource groups.
trans-unit.target: Use the Azure Portal to create an Azure virtual machine (VM) running Linux with the Azure resource groups.

trans-unit.source: Creating an Azure virtual machine (VM) that runs Linux is easy to do.
trans-unit.target: Creating an Azure virtual machine (VM) that runs Linux is easy to do.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use the Azure Preview portal to create one quickly, and uses the `~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub` public key file to secure your **SSH** connection to the VM.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use the Azure Preview portal to create one quickly, and uses the `~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub` public key file to secure your **SSH** connection to the VM.

trans-unit.source: You can also create Linux VMs using [your own images as templates](virtual-machines-linux-create-upload-vhd.md).
trans-unit.target: You can also create Linux VMs using [your own images as templates](virtual-machines-linux-create-upload-vhd.md).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This tutorial creates an Azure virtual machine that is managed by the Azure resource group API.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This tutorial creates an Azure virtual machine that is managed by the Azure resource group API.

trans-unit.source: For details, see [Azure resource group overview](resource-group-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: For details, see [Azure resource group overview](resource-group-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: Select the image
trans-unit.target: Select the image

trans-unit.source: Go to the Azure Marketplace in the Preview portal to find the Windows Server VM image you want.
trans-unit.target: Go to the Azure Marketplace in the Preview portal to find the Windows Server VM image you want.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the [Preview portal](https://portal.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the [Preview portal](https://portal.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: On the Hub menu, click **New** > **Compute** > **Ubuntu Server 14.04 LTS**.
trans-unit.target: On the Hub menu, click **New** > **Compute** > **Ubuntu Server 14.04 LTS**.

trans-unit.source: choosing a VM image
trans-unit.target: choosing a VM image

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] To find additional images, click **Marketplace** and then search or filter for available items.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] To find additional images, click **Marketplace** and then search or filter for available items.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the **Ubuntu Server 14.04 LTS** page, select **Use the Resource Manager stack** to create the VM in Azure Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the **Ubuntu Server 14.04 LTS** page, select **Use the Resource Manager stack** to create the VM in Azure Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Note that for most new workloads, we recommend the Resource Manager stack.
trans-unit.target: Note that for most new workloads, we recommend the Resource Manager stack.

trans-unit.source: For considerations, see [Azure Compute, Network and Storage Providers under the Azure Resource Manager](virtual-machines-azurerm-versus-azuresm.md).
trans-unit.target: For considerations, see [Azure Compute, Network and Storage Providers under the Azure Resource Manager](virtual-machines-azurerm-versus-azuresm.md).

trans-unit.source: Next, click
trans-unit.target: Next, click

trans-unit.source: create button
trans-unit.target: create button

trans-unit.source: change to the resource manager compute stack
trans-unit.target: change to the resource manager compute stack

trans-unit.source: Create the virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Create the virtual machine

trans-unit.source: After you select the image, you can use Azure's default settings for most of the configuration and quickly create the VM.
trans-unit.target: After you select the image, you can use Azure's default settings for most of the configuration and quickly create the VM.

trans-unit.source: On the **Create virtual machine** blade, click **Basics**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Create virtual machine** blade, click **Basics**.

trans-unit.source: Enter a **Name** you want for the VM, and a public key file (in **ssh-rsa** format, in this case from the `~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub` file).
trans-unit.target: Enter a **Name** you want for the VM, and a public key file (in **ssh-rsa** format, in this case from the `~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub` file).

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one subscription, specify the one for the new VM, as well as a new or existing **Resource group** and an Azure datacenter **Location**.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one subscription, specify the one for the new VM, as well as a new or existing **Resource group** and an Azure datacenter **Location**.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You may also choose username/password authentication here and enter that information if you do not want to secure your **ssh** session with a public and private key exchange.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You may also choose username/password authentication here and enter that information if you do not want to secure your **ssh** session with a public and private key exchange.

trans-unit.source: Click **Size** and select an appropriate VM size for your needs.
trans-unit.target: Click **Size** and select an appropriate VM size for your needs.

trans-unit.source: Each size specifies the number of compute cores, memory, and other features, such as support for Premium Storage, which will affect the price.
trans-unit.target: Each size specifies the number of compute cores, memory, and other features, such as support for Premium Storage, which will affect the price.

trans-unit.source: Azure recommends certain sizes automatically depending on the image you choose.
trans-unit.target: Azure recommends certain sizes automatically depending on the image you choose.

trans-unit.source: When done, click ![select button](media/virtual-machines-linux-tutorial-portal-rm/selectbutton-size.png).
trans-unit.target: When done, click ![select button](media/virtual-machines-linux-tutorial-portal-rm/selectbutton-size.png).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Premium storage is available for DS-series virtual machines in certain regions.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Premium storage is available for DS-series virtual machines in certain regions.

trans-unit.source: Premium storage is the best storage option for data intensive workloads such as a database.
trans-unit.target: Premium storage is the best storage option for data intensive workloads such as a database.

trans-unit.source: For details, see [Premium Storage: High-Performance Storage for Azure Virtual Machine Workloads](storage-premium-storage-preview-portal.md).
trans-unit.target: For details, see [Premium Storage: High-Performance Storage for Azure Virtual Machine Workloads](storage-premium-storage-preview-portal.md).

trans-unit.source: Click **Settings** to see storage and networking settings for the new VM.
trans-unit.target: Click **Settings** to see storage and networking settings for the new VM.

trans-unit.source: For a first VM you can generally accept the default settings.
trans-unit.target: For a first VM you can generally accept the default settings.

trans-unit.source: If you selected a VM size that supports it, you can try out Premium Storage by selecting **Premium (SSD)** under **Disk type**.
trans-unit.target: If you selected a VM size that supports it, you can try out Premium Storage by selecting **Premium (SSD)** under **Disk type**.

trans-unit.source: When done, click ![OK button](media/virtual-machines-linux-tutorial-portal-rm/okbutton.png).
trans-unit.target: When done, click ![OK button](media/virtual-machines-linux-tutorial-portal-rm/okbutton.png).

trans-unit.source: Click **Summary** to review your configuration choices.
trans-unit.target: Click **Summary** to review your configuration choices.

trans-unit.source: When you're done reviewing or updating the settings, click ![OK button](media/virtual-machines-linux-tutorial-portal-rm/createbutton.png) .
trans-unit.target: When you're done reviewing or updating the settings, click ![OK button](media/virtual-machines-linux-tutorial-portal-rm/createbutton.png) .

trans-unit.source: creation summary
trans-unit.target: creation summary

trans-unit.source: While Azure creates the VM, you can track the progress in **Notifications**, in the Hub menu.
trans-unit.target: While Azure creates the VM, you can track the progress in **Notifications**, in the Hub menu.

trans-unit.source: After Azure creates the VM, you'll see it on your Startboard unless you cleared **Pin to Startboard** in the **Create virtual machine** blade.
trans-unit.target: After Azure creates the VM, you'll see it on your Startboard unless you cleared **Pin to Startboard** in the **Create virtual machine** blade.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Note that the summary does not contain a public DNS name the way it does when a VM is created inside a Cloud Service using the service management compute stack.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Note that the summary does not contain a public DNS name the way it does when a VM is created inside a Cloud Service using the service management compute stack.

trans-unit.source: Connect to your Azure Linux VM using **ssh**
trans-unit.target: Connect to your Azure Linux VM using **ssh**

trans-unit.source: Now you can connect to your Ubuntu VM using **ssh** in the standard way.
trans-unit.target: Now you can connect to your Ubuntu VM using **ssh** in the standard way.

trans-unit.source: However, you're going to need to discover the IP address allocated to the Azure VM by opening the tile for the VM and its resources.
trans-unit.target: However, you're going to need to discover the IP address allocated to the Azure VM by opening the tile for the VM and its resources.

trans-unit.source: You can either do this by clicking **Browse**, then selecting **Recent** and looking for the VM you created, or clicking the tile created for you on the Startboard.
trans-unit.target: You can either do this by clicking **Browse**, then selecting **Recent** and looking for the VM you created, or clicking the tile created for you on the Startboard.

trans-unit.source: In either case, locate and copy the **Public IP Address** value, shown in the following graphic.
trans-unit.target: In either case, locate and copy the **Public IP Address** value, shown in the following graphic.

trans-unit.source: Now you can **ssh** into your Azure VM, and you're ready to go.
trans-unit.target: Now you can **ssh** into your Azure VM, and you're ready to go.

trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can also configure a fully qualified domain name (FQDN) for your virtual machine in the portal.
